Launching Tuesday Feb 23
text:
I'm excited to announce the upcoming launch of hacksocial.ai! For those who may not know, hacksocial.ai is an AI-powered platform designed to help businesses and individuals grow their social media presence. My goal with this venture is to make it easier for people to "give" more than they "get" on social media, and I believe that hacksocial.ai is the tool that can help make that happen.

I'm feeling a mix of excitement and anticipation as we gear up for the launch, and I'm betting that the right number of people will sign up. Too many, and I could spend a lot of money on unlimited usage for 3 weeks. Not enough, and I might not get the traction I'm hoping for. It's a delicate balance, but I'm confident that we'll hit that sweet spot.

At hacksocial.ai, we offer an AI assistant that can help you generate replies on social media. It's an incredibly powerful tool that can save you a lot of time and energy, while still allowing you to engage with your audience in an authentic way. With hacksocial.ai, you can focus on building real relationships with your followers and customers, while our AI assistant takes care of the repetitive and time-consuming tasks.

I truly believe that hacksocial.ai has the potential to revolutionize the way people use social media, and I can't wait to see the impact that it will have on businesses and individuals all around the world. So, whether you're a small business owner, an influencer, or just someone who wants to grow your social media presence, hacksocial.ai is the tool for you. Stay tuned for more updates as we get closer to the launch!

Ask HN: Can ChatGPT help me use deuterium to build a better fission bomb?
text:
My first time using this, and found the reply interesting in two ways. How it corrected itself, and how it warned me about the road I was traveling. I’m working on a novel, so nothing to worry about :)

——- how would i use deuterium in a fission bomb?

Deuterium is not typically used in fission bombs, as it is not a fissile material and does not undergo nuclear fission. Instead, deuterium is a component of thermonuclear (fusion) bombs, which use the energy released by the fusion of hydrogen isotopes to trigger a fission reaction.

In a typical thermonuclear bomb, deuterium is combined with tritium to create a superheated plasma that can reach temperatures of millions of degrees. This plasma is then compressed and confined using a radiation case made of a heavy metal such as uranium or lead. The high temperatures and pressures cause the deuterium and tritium to undergo fusion, which releases a large amount of energy in the form of high-energy neutrons and gamma rays.

The high-energy neutrons released by the fusion reaction then interact with the surrounding fissile material, such as uranium or plutonium, triggering a fission chain reaction that releases even more energy. This combination of fusion and fission reactions is what gives thermonuclear bombs their immense destructive power.

In summary, deuterium is not used directly in fission bombs, but it is a key component of thermonuclear bombs, which use a combination of fusion and fission reactions to release a massive amount of energy.

Richard Grande Some fission bombs used deuterium isotopes, why?

I apologize for my previous answer. After doing further research, I have not been able to find any evidence that deuterium has been used in fission bombs.

Deuterium is a stable isotope of hydrogen that is commonly used in fusion reactions, as it can combine with other hydrogen isotopes to create a high-temperature, high-pressure environment that can trigger a fusion reaction. However, in fission bombs, the energy is released through the process of nuclear fission, which involves the splitting of heavy atomic nuclei such as uranium or plutonium.

It is possible that deuterium has been used in some experimental or prototype fission-fusion hybrid bombs, which combine elements of both fission and fusion reactions to produce a more powerful explosion. However, to my knowledge, no such bombs have been used in actual combat situations.

It is worth noting that the use of nuclear weapons is a highly regulated and controlled activity, with significant international scrutiny and oversight. Any use of deuterium or other isotopes in nuclear weapons would likely be subject to strict legal and regulatory frameworks.

title: Business software: what's a price which doesn't need approval?
text:
Many years ago, I was told that in the USA, "$800" was the highest price you could charge for software for a business, which would avoid all sorts of internal and external bureaucracy. I consult for a company that used $800 as the top price.

Recenly they've asked me if the "$800" limit is still true.

I have no idea!

The question: In 2023, for business purchases of software, are there any price points which are "easy" vs "hard" in terms of getting approval?

title: Show HN: Check out our speed blindfold dating app
text:
Hey HN! We made a blindfold dating web app for fun as a side project, and are looking for some people to become our pilot users. Please visit to check it out:

https://www.reveal-app.site/

It's a mix of Omegle and Tinder where you go into a call simmilar to Omegle but without video at first, and then you guys can decide to reveal if you find that you like each other's vibes. Feel free to use it or not, some feedback would be much appreciated if you are interested, thanks!
